Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hybrid Organic-Inorganic Thermoelectric Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal 1400246
Collaborative Research: Hybrid organic-inorganic thermoelectric materials

Abstract:

Thermoelectric materials are materials which can be used to convert thermal energy directly to electricity. The performance of a thermoelectric material is measured by the "figure of merit", termed ZT. There has been much research into increasing thermoelectric materials, figure of merit, however, progress in this area has been slow and most of the researched thermoelectric materials up to now are suffering from either high fabrication cost, usage of rare earth or toxic elements, or poor mechanical properties. Organic thermoelectric materials (OTEs) have recently attracted attention for low temperature applications (< 300K), especially cooling purposes, as they are flexible, low-cost and abundant, and low-cost fabrication methods for synthesizing them exist. However, the ZT of the state-of-the-art OTEs is significantly lower than the ZT of their inorganic counterparts. In fact, there are only few candidates for low temperature thermoelectric devices even among inorganic materials. In the case of inorganic thermoelectric materials, the limiting factor in improving ZT is the electron mobility. This work will allow for the fabrication of high-ZT thermoelectric materials by addressing the challenges in mobility enhancement. This will be done by combining the two classes of materials (organic and inorganic), using a fabrication scheme in which high-mobility inorganic nanowires are embedded inside organic compounds. The researchers are a multidisciplinary team with complementary expertise and with common interest in the thermoelectric field. Graduate and Undergraduate Students involved in this project therefore will benefit largely from the multidisciplinary nature of the work.

This work is applying new doping schemes (3D modulation-doping and field-effect doping) to hybrid organic-inorganic materials and to simulate, design, fabricate and characterize a new class of low temperature thermoelectric nanocomposites. The two-phase material uses the organic phase (e.g. conjugated-polymer or organic molecules) as a source of electrons and the inorganic semiconducting phase (e.g. Si nanowires) as the electron transport channel with high mobility. The key is to use the modulation-doping scheme to favor carrier transfer from the source of carriers (e.g. conjugated-polymer) to the high mobility inorganic semiconducting phase (inorganic nanowires) and optimize the carrier concentration to design a high Z hybrid thermoelectric material. A large class of semiconducting nanostructures (e.g. Si, CdTe, Bi, and PbTe nanowires and holely structures) combined with conjugated polymers (e.g., chemically-modified PEDOT and low bandgap polymers) and organic molecules (specifically charged chemical species attached to molecules such as CF3- substituted styrene molecules) will be simulated, synthesized and optimized to identify new hybrid materials with a potentially high ZT.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of the project is manifested in understanding the energy filtering effect of PEDOT/PbTe organic/inorganic nanohybrids that build on the materials-by-design concept and tuning thermoelectric properties of these hybrids through engineering the molecular weight of PEDOT and the doping level and nanoscopic morphologies of PbTe nanocrystals. As a collaborative project, the PI crafted PbS and PbTe nanoparticles of different diameters through the precise molecular design decorated with well-defined conducting polymer PEDOT via Grignard metathesis (GRIM) polymerization and click reaction, rendering the formation of organic/inorganic nanohybrids. As such, thermoelectric properties are expected to be enhanced due to the energy filtering effect at organic/inorganic interface. In particular, the PI crafted (a) monodisperse hollow PbTe and PbS nanocrystals intimately and permanently tethered with conjugated polymer PEDOT with can act as the conductive organic matrix with low thermal conductivity for thermoelectric organic/inorganic hybrid materials and devices, and (b) well-defined CdS nanorods intimately and permanently tethered with conjugated polymer P3HT which not only serve as stabilizing surface ligands but also allows in-situ synthesis of hybrid materials composed of P3HT as matrix and CdS nanorods as nanofiller.

The broader impact of the project include strong nanoscience education. Two undergraduate students including one from underrepresented group have been recruited to participate in the research project. One PhD student has been trained under the support of this project for three years. This project allows the PhD studnet to synthesize nanostructured thermoelectric materials with well-controlled dimensions and learn the thermoelectric property of the resulting thermoelectric nanohybrids. Knowledge generated in this project may lead to the development of thermoelectric materials and devices with improved performance.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/14/2017
Modified by: Zhiqun Lin

  • Stepwise representation of crafting low bandgap hollow thermoelectric nanoparticles with tunable dimensions and surface chemistry by utilizing star-like PS-b-PAA-b-PS or PS-b-PAA-b-PEDOT triblock copolymers, respectively, as nanoreactors.
    Yanjie He
    Copyrighted
    Zhiqun Lin
    Hollow Thermoelectric Nanoparticles

As a collaborative project, the PI crafted PbS and PbTe nanoparticles of different diameters through the precise molecular design decorated with well-defined conducting polymer PEDOT via Grignard metathesis (GRIM) polymerization and click reaction, rendering the formation of organic/inorganic nanohybrids. As such, thermoelectric properties are expected to be enhanced due to the energy filtering effect at organic/inorganic interface. In particular, the PI crafted (a) monodisperse hollow PbTe and PbS nanocrystals intimately and permanently tethered with conjugated polymer PEDOT with can act as the conductive organic matrix with low thermal conductivity for thermoelectric organic/inorganic hybrid materials and devices, and (b) well-defined CdS nanorods intimately and permanently tethered with conjugated polymer P3HT which not only serve as stabilizing surface ligands but also allows in-situ synthesis of hybrid materials composed of P3HT as matrix and CdS nanorods as nanofiller. The broader impact of the project include strong nanoscience education. Two undergraduate students including one from underrepresented group have been recruited to participate in the research project. One PhD student has been trained under the support of this project for three years. This project allows the PhD studnet to synthesize nanostructured thermoelectric materials with well-controlled dimensions and learn the thermoelectric property of the resulting thermoelectric nanohybrids. Knowledge generated in this project may lead to the development of thermoelectric materials and devices with improved performance. Last Modified: 08/14/2017 Submitted by: Zhiqun Lin
